none: 25/1348 Settlement of claim re fire insurance on the Town hall

body.value: Title: Amount received for oil paintings
Description: The last part of the insurance claim - for the paintings of Lord Mayors and Town Clerks destroyed in the fire - was not settled until the end of 1926.

Description: Leslie, the insurance adjuster, was keen to finalise the settlement, and wrote to Town Clerk McCall in a personal capacity to plead with him (unsuccessfully) to bypass the slow machinery of the Council bureacracy.
Description: It seems that haggling over estimates for the Town Hall reconstruction in long, dull meetings gave City Engineer Henry Morton time to doodle on his notes.
Title: Lady Mayoress' and Councillors Wives' Rooms
Description: Wives of the Lord Mayor and councillors were provided with rooms in the Town Hall to receive and entertain guests - predominantly in connection with charitable fundraising activities.
Title: Dancing floor, bio box and organ
Description: Reconstruction of the Town Hall provided an interesting insight into its main uses - the large space could be booked for dances, film screenings and musical concerts.

Description: Settling the Town Hall insurance claim required lengthy negotiations over the amounts for damage. This copy - issued to and annotated by City Engineer Henry Morton - is one of nearly a dozen drafts in the correspondence file.
Description: As a result of the fire and the water used by the fire brigade, the next door Coffee Palace suffered minor damage, paid for by the Council's insurers.

Description: After a career in management of some of Australia's largest insurance companies, F. F. Leslie went into business as an insurance adjuster - liaising between insurers and their clients on the value of losses - in the mid-1910s, and by the 1920s was one of the most well-reputed adjusters in Melbourne business circles.
